name: places/ChIJv3HY4ib2wokRNED9EHjJdZI
formattedAddress: 788 Columbus Ave, New York, NY 10025, USA
adrFormatAddress: 788 Columbus Ave, New York, NY 10025, USA

originalText.text: I moved out over 3 months ago and am still owed thousands of dollars. While living there...there was a ton of construction, the walls are very thin, kids playing and screaming in the hallways all the time, laundry stolen out of the laundry room, back door entrance left open very often where anyone could walk in, mice in our apartment multiple times. After all of that in just 14 months I would have never taken the time out of my day to write this but the fact that now I have been trying to get back what I am owed for over three months goes to show how bad this management company really is. Do not be fooled by the concession deals they promise you.

originalText.text: What a mistake to move here.  This is an old NYC rent controlled building/complex that's made a few changes and renovation to emptied apartments to try to pass as a high end UWS rental. It's still operated like an old rent-control building with poor maintenance. We're paying market rates for what is marketed as a one bedroom when it's actually a large studio with a sliding door dividing the living room and tiny bedroom.  It wouldn't be so bad if the facility and maintence made up for the high rent.  Elevators are not kept clear, hall corridor floors are rarely vacuumed,  lobby elevators are a mess of rust, plaint, neglect - we were made to believe that there was construction going on that would leave all in excelent condition.  It's  We were scamed.   Now we're stuck with an 18 month lease.  Be warey.....

originalText.text:
Please note that Park West Village Tenants Association is NOT the same as the management of Park West Village, nor associated with it in any way, except to advocate for the tenants, and therefore to maintain dialogue with management as necessary.  PWVTA has voluntary membership dues and voluntary participation.

PWVTA represents and advocates for ALL  2500 tenants in the seven buildings, including condo owners, statutory (rent stabilized) tenants, and market-rate tenants.  Although many past issues and victories focus on rights of statutory tenants (such as opposition to MCI rent increases,) all tenants benefit from improved services, more reliable and convenient mail and package delivery, cleaner laundry rooms, better security at entries and exits, responsible use of dog runs including odor and noise there, consistent maintenance of trees and plantings, acknowledgment of interest on security deposit for all tenants, and especially the vigorous opposition of construction on open space.

Despite occasional serious issues with management, we have loved living here for more than 42 years.
